question.title: How to create polymorphic/generic many-to-many relationship in Hibernate?

node.contents: I would like to create a generic many-to-many relationship (List).

astNode.text: I would like to create a generic many-to-many relationship (List).

node.contents: I woulk like to create a generic link association like the following, where from and to may be any of the domain objects above.

astNode.text: I woulk like to create a generic link association like the following, where from and to may be any of the domain objects above.

node.contents: So Issue has-many Link, where the issue is in one side of the relationship.

astNode.text: So Issue has-many Link, where the issue is in one side of the relationship.

node.contents: I envisage using a link table that will look something like the following:

astNode.text: I envisage using a link table that will look something like the following:

elements.contents: Link Table | ID | SRC_ID | SRC_CLASS | DEST_ID | DESC_CLASS |

units.rawText: Link Table | ID | SRC_ID | SRC_CLASS | DEST_ID | DESC_CLASS |

node.contents: So SRC_ID and DEST_ID are foreign keys into the appropriate table.

astNode.text: So SRC_ID and DEST_ID are foreign keys into the appropriate table.

node.contents: What should the mapping for the Link table look like?

astNode.text: What should the mapping for the Link table look like?

node.contents: Yes I understand all that - but the reason for adding in an example for the table structure was to give you an idea for what I am looking for. Since the `to` and `from` ends of the relation can be multiple types, I'm not sure how to code the Link itself

astNode.text: Yes I understand all that - but the reason for adding in an example for the table structure was to give you an idea for what I am looking for. Since the `to` and `from` ends of the relation can be multiple types, I'm not sure how to code the Link itself

node.contents: In Hibernate you should not manually create table from Entity class. Just put annotation @ManyToMany to your pojo and hibernate will generate schema of your database with all your foreign key relationship with related tables.

astNode.text: In Hibernate you should not manually create table from Entity class. Just put annotation @ManyToMany to your pojo and hibernate will generate schema of your database with all your foreign key relationship with related tables.

elements.contents: @Entity class Issue{ @ManyToMany List<Link> links; } @Entity class Link{ }

units.rawText: @Entity class Issue{ @ManyToMany List<Link> links; } @Entity class Link{ }

node.contents: If your application is Java SE, then use class SchemaExport to generate schema in database.

astNode.text: If your application is Java SE, then use class SchemaExport to generate schema in database.

node.contents: I have implemented this relationship by externalising it entirely from the domain objects.

astNode.text: I have implemented this relationship by externalising it entirely from the domain objects.

elements.contents: class Link{ String fromClass long fromId String toClass long toId String description Link(){} Link(Object src, Object dest, String descrption){ fromClass=src.class.name fromId=src.id toClass=dest.class.name toId=dest.id this.description=description } Object getFrom(){ // Invoke GORM static finder Class.forName(fromClass)."get"(fromId) } Object getTo(){ // Invoke GORM static finder Class.forName(toClass)."get"(toId) } }

declarations.text: String fromClass long fromId String toClass long toId String description Link()
Link(Object src, Object dest, String descrption){ fromClass=src.class.name fromId=src.id toClass=dest.class.name toId=dest.id this.description=description

comments.text: // Invoke GORM static finder Class.forName(fromClass)."get"(fromId) } Object getTo(){ // Invoke GORM static finder Class.forName(toClass)."get"(toId) } }

node.contents: With an associated service layer to create/retrieve the objects:

astNode.text: With an associated service layer to create/retrieve the objects:

elements.contents: import org.springframework.transaction.annotation.Transactional class LinkableService { @Transactional public void link(Object src, Object dest, String description){ Link link = new Link(src,dest,description) link.save() } @Transactional(readOnly=true) public Collection<Link> links(Object subject){ def fromLinks = Link.findAllWhere(fromClass:subject.class.name, fromId:subject.id) def toLinks = Link.findAllWhere(toClass:subject.class.name, toId:subject.id) def allLinks = new ArrayList<Link>(fromLinks) allLinks.addAll(toLinks) return allLinks } }

declarations.text: @Transactional public void link(Object src, Object dest, String description){ Link link = new Link(src,dest,description) link.save()

units.rawText: import orgspringframeworktransactionannotationTransactional class LinkableService { @Transactional public void link(Object src, Object dest, String description){ Link link = new Link(src,dest,description) link.save() } @Transactional(readOnly=true) public Collection<Link> links(Object subject){ def fromLinks = LinkfindAllWhere(fromClass:subject.class.name, fromId:subject.id) def toLinks = LinkfindAllWhere(toClass:subject.class.name, toId:subject.id) def allLinks = new ArrayList<Link>(fromLinks) allLinksaddAll(toLinks) return allLinks } }

node.contents: I am a little concerned about performance, but as I only expect to be working with small datasets it should not be a major issue. And without metrics, I won't optimise yet!

astNode.text: I am a little concerned about performance, but as I only expect to be working with small datasets it should not be a major issue. And without metrics, I won't optimise yet!
